title: The cbcTools Package: Tools for Designing and Testing Choice-Based Conjoint Surveys in R
description: My talk for the 2022 Sawtooth Software Conference
contents:
I gave a talk at the Sawtooth
Software Conference in Orlando, FL, on May 06, 2022. The talk is
titled, ‚ÄúThe {cbcTools} Package: Tools for Designing and Testing
Choice-Based Conjoint Surveys in R‚Äù.
Learn more about the {cbcTools} package here: https://jhelvy.github.io/cbcTools/
Talk

title: Interview with CGTN Full Frame: Going Green
description: I was featured in a long-form interview with CGTN discussing the challenges and opportunities China faces in the race to decarbonize it's energy systems.
contents:
I was featured in a long-form interview on an episode of CGTN‚Äôs ‚ÄúFull Frame‚Äù. In
the interview,
I discuss some of the challenges and opportunities China faces in the
race to decarbonize it‚Äôs energy systems. I also discuss the critical
role China is playing in scaling up the mass production of low carbon
energy technologies like solar panels, wind turbines, lithium-ion
batteries, and electric vehicles. My interview starts at minute 30:45 in
the show, which you can watch here.

title: ISA Industrial Policy Webinar Series: Taking Charge
description: I moderated the ISA Webinar on "Batteries for Electric Vehicles and the Transformation of the Automotive Supply Chain"
contents:
On December 1, 2021, I had the honor of moderating the Industry Studies Association (ISA) webinar on the future of batteries for electric vehicles, as part of its ongoing webinar series on industrial policy. You can watch the recording below.
About the webinar:
The auto industry is on the cusp of its greatest transformation in more than a century, shifting from internal combustion engines to electric motors powered by lithium-ion batteries. China, which already plays an important role in global auto supply chains, has been the first mover in this transformation, sparking concerns in the United States and elsewhere. This session will explore the United States‚Äô proposed response to this challenge and its profound links to both long-run economic prosperity and the future of the planet.
Moderator: John Paul Helveston, Assistant Professor, Engineering Management & Systems Engineering, George Washington University
Administration Presenter: Susan Helper, Senior Economist, White House Council of Economic Advisers
Discussants:
George W. Crabtree, Director, Joint Center for Energy Storage Research, Argonne National Laboratory
Kristin Dziczek, Senior Vice President ‚Äì Research, Center for Automotive Research
John Paul MacDuffie, President, Industry Studies Association, and Professor of Management, University of Pennsylvania

title: Obtaining Willingness to Pay Estimates from Preference Space and Willingness to Pay Space Utility Models
description: My talk for the 2021 Sawtooth Conference Turbo Choice Modeling Panel
contents:
I gave a talk at the Sawtooth Software Conference Turbo Choice Modeling Seminar in San Antonio, Texas, April 19-23, 2021 (I pre-recorded my talk as I did not attend in-person). The talk is titled, ‚ÄúThe {logitr} R Package: Obtaining Willingness to Pay Estimates from Preference Space and Willingness to Pay Space Utility Models‚Äù.

title: Using formr to create R-powered surveys with individualized feedback
description: My rstudio::conf 2021 lightning talk on creating R-powered surveys using {formr}"
contents:
Contents
Watch the talk
Slides
Surveys with {formr}

Watch the talk
I gave a lightning talk at the 2021 rstudio conference on using {formr} to create R-powered surveys.

 Watch the lightning talk

I also gave an extended version of the talk at the GW Coders Meetup on Feb.¬†19, 2021. You can see that below (the first 5 minutes is the same as my rstudio::conf lightning talk):


Slides
Here are my slides for my rstudio::conf lightning talk built using the {xaringan} R package. You can also see the source code for the slides here.

 Full screen slides Slides as PDF

Keyboard Shortcuts for Slides:
Use ‚Üê and ‚Üí to navigate through the slides.
Use f to toggle full screen.
Use o to view an overview of all slides.
Use h to see a list of other shortcuts.





Surveys with {formr}
In my presentation, I showed several examples of how to use the {formr} package to create different types of surveys. The surveys are all generated from Google sheets, which can be found here:
Random images demonstrates how to randomly display different images.
Conjoint surveys demonstrates how to create a conjoint survey with formr (go to the formr4conjoint repo for a more detailed description)
Timed quizzes demonstrates how to create a timed quiz with randomly generated questions.
To use any of these surveys yourself, go to formr.org, create an account. Once you log in, go to the admin page and create a new survey. You can then paste in the link to the Google sheet there. If you want to edit it, just create copy of the Google sheet into your own Google Drive account and use the shared link to that Google sheet.
Once you have a survey uploaded, you can make it live by creating a ‚ÄúRun‚Äù and inserting the survey you created by clicking on the icon as well as a ‚ÄúStop‚Äù point to end the survey by clicking on the icon. The link to the survey will be https://your_run_name.formr.org.
You can control the ‚Äúpublicness‚Äù of the survey by modifying the ‚Äúvolume‚Äù icons:
means only you can access the survey
means you and people who have an access code can access (no new users can enroll).
means people who have the link can access.
means the link is public, everyone can access.

title: U. Albany Confucius Institute Fall 2020 Seminar on US-China Relations in the 21st Century
description: My discussion with Barry Naughton (UCSD) about industrial policy and low-carbon energy technologies in China
contents:
Barry Naughton (Sokwanlok Chair of Chinese International Affairs at the School of Global Policy and Strategy, UCSD) and I kicked off the U. of Albany Confucius Institute Fall 2020 Seminar Series on ‚ÄúUS-China Relations in the 21st Century‚Äù with a discussion about industrial policy and low-carbon energy technologies in China. In his presentation titled, ‚ÄúChina‚Äôs Industrial Policy: New Technological Revolution or Old-fashioned Protectionism?‚Äù, Professor Naughton highlighted some of the recent major technology and industrial policy changes under President Xi and the implications for the U.S. In my talk titled, ‚ÄúChina‚Äôs key role in scaling low carbon energy technologies,‚Äù I discussed the critical role China has played in scaling up the mass production of low-carbon energy technologies, such as solar photovoltaic cells and lithium-ion batteries, highlighting key points from my related paper in Science with Jonas Nahm.

 Slides as PDF Science Paper
